00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 extraAnswerEvaluators.pl - Answer evaluators for intervals, lists of numbers,
00020 and lists of points.
00021 
00022 =head1 SYNPOSIS
00023 
00024     interval_cmp() -- checks answers which are unions of intervals. It can also
00025                       be used for checking an ordered pair or list of ordered
00026                       pairs.
00027 
00028     number_list_cmp() -- checks a comma separated list of numbers.  By use of
00029                          optional arguments, you can request that order be
00030                          important, that complex numbers be allowed, and specify
00031                          extra arguments to be sent to num_cmp (or cplx_cmp) for
00032                          checking individual entries.
00033 
00034     equation_cmp() -- provides a limited facility for checking equations. It
00035                       makes no pretense of checking to see if the real locus of
00036                       the student's equation matches the real locus of the
00037                       instructor's equation.  The student's equation must be of
00038                       the same general type as the instructors to get credit.
00039 
00040 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00041 
00042 This file adds subroutines which create "answer evaluators" for checking student
00043 answers of various "exotic" types.
00044 
00045 =cut
00046 
00047 # ^uses loadMacros
00048 loadMacros('MathObjects.pl');
00049 
00050 {
00051     # ^package Equation_eval
00052     package Equation_eval;
00053     
00054     # ^function split_eqn
00055     sub split_eqn {
00056         my $instring = shift;
00057         
00058         split /=/, $instring;
00059     }
00060     
00061     #FIXME  -- this could be improved so that
00062     #          1. it uses an answer evaluator object instead of a sub routine
00063     #          2. it provides error messages when previous answers are equivalent
00064     # ^function equation_cmp
00065     # ^uses AnswerHash::new
00066     # ^uses split_eqn
00067     # ^uses main::check_syntax
00068     # ^uses main::fun_cmp
00069     sub equation_cmp {
00070         my $right_ans = shift;
00071         my %opts = @_;
00072         my $vars = ['x','y'];
00073 
00074 
00075         $vars = $opts{'vars'} if defined($opts{'vars'});
00076 
00077         my $ans_eval = sub {
00078             my $student = shift;
00079             my %response_options = @_;
00080             my $ans_hash = new AnswerHash(
00081                 'score'=>0,
00082                 'correct_ans'=>$right_ans,
00083                 'student_ans'=>$student,
00084                 'original_student_ans' => $student,
00085                 'type' => 'equation_cmp',
00086                 'ans_message'=>'',
00087                 'preview_text_string'=>'',
00088                 'preview_latex_string'=>'',
00089             );
00090 
00091             if(! ($student =~ /\S/)) { return $ans_hash; }
00092 
00093             my @right= split_eqn($right_ans);
00094             if(scalar(@right) != 2) {
00095                 $ans_hash->{'ans_message'} = "Tell your professor that there is an error in this problem.";
00096                 return $ans_hash;
00097             }
00098             my @studsplit = split_eqn($student);
00099             if(scalar(@studsplit) != 2) {
00100                 $ans_hash->{'ans_message'} = "You did not enter an equation (with an equals sign and two sides).";
00101                 return $ans_hash;
00102             }
00103 
00104             # Next we should do syntax checks on everyone
00105 
00106             my $ah = new AnswerHash;
00107             $ah->input($right[0]);
00108             $ah=main::check_syntax($ah);
00109             if($ah->{error_flag}) {
00110                 $ans_hash->{'ans_message'} = "Tell your professor that there is an error in this problem.";
00111                 return $ans_hash;
00112             }
00113 
00114             $ah->input($right[1]);
00115             $ah=main::check_syntax($ah);
00116             if($ah->{error_flag}) {
00117                 $ans_hash->{'ans_message'} = "Tell your professor that there is an error in this problem.";
00118                 return $ans_hash;
00119             }
00120 
00121             # Correct answer checks out, now check student's syntax
00122 
00123             my @prevs = ("","");
00124             my @prevtxt = ("","");
00125             $ah->input($studsplit[0]);
00126             $ah=main::check_syntax($ah);
00127             if($ah->{error_flag}) {
00128                 $ans_hash->{'ans_message'} = "Syntax error on the left side of your equation.";
00129                 return $ans_hash;
00130             }
00131             $prevs[0] = $ah->{'preview_latex_string'};
00132             $prevstxt[0] = $ah->{'preview_text_string'};
00133 
00134 
00135             $ah->input($studsplit[1]);
00136             $ah=main::check_syntax($ah);
00137             if($ah->{error_flag}) {
00138                 $ans_hash->{'ans_message'} = "Syntax error on the right side of your equation.";
00139                 return $ans_hash;
00140             }
00141             $prevs[1] = $ah->{'preview_latex_string'};
00142             $prevstxt[1] = $ah->{'preview_text_string'};
00143 
00144             $ans_hash->{'preview_latex_string'} = "$prevs[0] = $prevs[1]";
00145             $ans_hash->{'preview_text_string'} = "$prevstxt[0] = $prevstxt[1]";
00146 
00147 
00148             # Check for answer equivalent to 0=0
00149             # Could be false positive below because of parameter
00150             my $ae = main::fun_cmp("0", %opts);
00151             my $res = $ae->evaluate("$studsplit[0]-($studsplit[1])");
00152             if($res->{'score'}==1) {
00153                 # Student is 0=0, is correct answer also like this?
00154                 $res = $ae->evaluate("$right[0]-($right[1])");
00155                 if($res->{'score'}==1) {
00156                     $ans_hash-> setKeys('score' => $res->{'score'});
00157                 }
00158                 return $ans_hash;
00159             }
00160 
00161             # Maybe answer really is 0=0, and student got it wrong, so check that
00162             $res = $ae->evaluate("$right[0]-($right[1])");
00163             if($res->{'score'}==1) {
00164                 return $ans_hash;
00165             }
00166 
00167             # Finally, use fun_cmp to check the answers
00168 
00169             $ae = main::fun_cmp("o*($right[0]-($right[1]))", vars=>$vars, params=>['o'], %opts);
00170             $res= $ae->evaluate("$studsplit[0]-($studsplit[1])",%response_options);
00171             $ans_hash-> setKeys('score' => $res->{'score'});
00172 
00173             return $ans_hash;
00174         };
00175 
00176         return $ans_eval;
00177     }
00178 }
00179 # ^package main

00181 # ^function mode2context
00182 # ^uses Parser::Context::getCopy
00183 # ^uses %context
00184 # ^uses $numZeroLevelTolDefault
00185 # ^uses $numAbsTolDefault
00186 # ^uses $numRelPercentTolDefault
00187 # ^uses $numFormatDefault
00188 sub mode2context {
00189     my $mode = shift;
00190     my %options = @_;
00191     my $context;
00192     for ($mode) {
00193         /^strict$/i  and do {
00194             $context = Parser::Context->getCopy(\%main::context,"LimitedNumeric");
00195             $context->operators->redefine(',');
00196             last;
00197         };
00198         /^arith$/i   and do {
00199             $context = Parser::Context->getCopy(\%main::context,"LegacyNumeric");
00200             $context->functions->disable('All');
00201             last;
00202         };
00203         /^frac$/i    and do {
00204             $context = Parser::Context->getCopy(\%main::context,"LimitedNumeric-Fraction");
00205             $context->operators->redefine(',');
00206             last;
00207         };
00208         
00209         # default
00210         $context = Parser::Context->getCopy(\%main::context,"LegacyNumeric");
00211     }
00212     # If we are using complex numbers, then we ignore the other mode parts
00213     if(defined($options{'complex'}) &&
00214        ($options{'complex'} =~ /(yes|ok)/i)) {
00215         #$context->constants->redefine('i', from=>'Complex');
00216         #$context->functions->redefine(['arg','mod','Re','Im','conj', 'sqrt', 'log'], from=>'Complex');
00217         #$context->operators->redefine(['^', '**'], from=>'Complex');
00218         $context = Parser::Context->getCopy(\%main::context,"Complex");
00219     }
00220     $options{tolType} = $options{tolType} || 'relative';
00221     $options{tolType} = 'absolute' if defined($options{tol});
00222     $options{zeroLevel} = $options{zeroLevel} || $options{zeroLevelTol} ||
00223         $main::numZeroLevelTolDefault;
00224     if ($options{tolType} eq 'absolute' or defined($options{abstol})) {
00225         $options{tolerance} = $options{tolerance} || $options{tol} ||
00226             $options{reltol} || $options{relTol} || $options{abstol} ||
00227             $main::numAbsTolDefault;
00228         $context->flags->set(
00229             tolerance => $options{tolerance},
00230             tolType => 'absolute',
00231             );
00232     } else {
00233         $options{tolerance} = $options{tolerance} || $options{tol} ||
00234             $options{reltol} || $options{relTol} || $options{abstol} ||
00235             $main::numRelPercentTolDefault;
00236         $context->flags->set(
00237             tolerance => .01*$options{tolerance},
00238             tolType => 'relative',
00239             );
00240     }
00241     $context->flags->set(
00242         zeroLevel => $options{zeroLevel},
00243         zeroLevelTol => $options{zeroLevelTol} || $main::numZeroLevelTolDefault,
00244         );
00245     $context->{format}{number} = $options{'format'} || $main::numFormatDefault;
00246     return($context);
00247 }
00248 
00249 =head1 MACROS
00250 
00251 =head2 interval_cmp
00252 
00253 Compares an interval or union of intervals.  Typical invocations are
00254 
00255     interval_cmp("(2, 3] U(7, 11)")
00256 
00257 The U is used for union symbol.  In fact, any garbage (or nothing at all) can go
00258 between intervals.  It makes sure open/closed parts of intervals are correct,
00259 unless you don't like that.  To have it ignore the difference between open and
00260 closed endpoints, use
00261 
00262     interval_cmp("(2, 3] U(7, 11)", sloppy=>'yes')
00263 
00264 interval_cmp uses num_cmp on the endpoints.  You can pass optional arguments for
00265 num_cmp, so to change the tolerance, you can use
00266 
00267     interval_cmp("(2, 3] U(3+4, 11)", relTol=>3)
00268 
00269 The intervals can be listed in any order, unless you want to force a
00270 particular order, which is signaled as
00271 
00272     interval_cmp("(2, 3] U(3+4, 11)", ordered=>'strict')
00273 
00274 You can specify infinity as an endpoint.  It will do a case-insensitive
00275 string match looking for I, Infinity, Infty, or Inf.  You can prepend a +
00276 or -, as in
00277 
00278     interval_cmp("(-inf, 3] U [e^10, infinity)")
00279 
00280 or
00281 
00282     interval_cmp("(-INF, 3] U [e^10, +I)")
00283 
00284 If the question might have an empty set as the answer, you can use
00285 the strings option to allow for it.  So
00286 
00287     interval_cmp("$ans", strings=>['empty'])
00288 
00289 will not generate an error message if the student enters the string
00290 empty.  Better still, it will mark a student answer of "empty" as correct
00291 iff this matches $ans.
00292 
00293 You can use interval_cmp for ordered pairs, or lists of ordered pairs.
00294 Internally, this is just a distinction of whether to put nice union symbols
00295 between intervals, or commas.  To get commas, use
00296 
00297     interval_cmp("(1,2), (2,3), (4,-1)", unions=>'no')
00298 
00299 Note that interval_cmp makes no attempt at simplifying overlapping intervals.
00300 This becomes an important feature when you are really checking lists of
00301 ordered pairs.
00302 
00303 Now we use the Parser package for checking intervals (or lists of
00304 points if unions=>'no').  So, one can specify the Parser options
00305 showCoordinateHints, showHints, partialCredit, and/or showLengthHints
00306 as optional arguments:
00307 
00308     interval_cmp("(1,2), (2,3), (4,-1)", unions=>'no', partialCredit=>1)
00309 
00310 Also, set differences and 'R' for all real numbers now work too since they work
00311 for Parser Intervals and Unions.
00312 
00313 =cut
00314 
00315 # ^function interval_cmp
00316 # ^uses Context
00317 # ^uses mode2context
00318 # ^uses List
00319 # ^uses Union
00320 sub interval_cmp {
00321     my $correct_ans = shift;
00322 
00323     my %opts = @_;
00324     
00325     my $mode          = $opts{mode} || 'std';
00326     my %options       = (debug => $opts{debug});
00327     my $ans_type = ''; # set to List, Union, or String below
00328     
00329     #
00330     #  Get an apppropriate context based on the mode
00331     #
00332     my $oldContext = Context();
00333     my $context = mode2context($mode, %opts);
00334 
00335     if(defined($opts{unions}) and $opts{unions} eq 'no' ) {
00336         # This is really a list of points, not intervals at all
00337         $ans_type = 'List';
00338         $context->parens->redefine('(');
00339         $context->parens->redefine('[');
00340         $context->parens->redefine('{');
00341         $context->operators->redefine('u',using=>',');
00342         $context->operators->set(u=>{string=>", ", TeX=>',\,'});
00343     } else {
00344         $context->parens->redefine('(', from=>'Interval');
00345         $context->parens->redefine('[', from=>'Interval');
00346         $context->parens->redefine('{', from=>'Interval');
00347         
00348         $context->constants->redefine('R',from=>'Interval');
00349         $context->operators->redefine('U',from=>"Interval");
00350         $context->operators->redefine('u',from=>"Interval",using=>"U");
00351         $ans_type = 'Union';
00352     }
00353     # Take optional arguments intended for List, or Union
00354     for my $o (qw( showCoordinateHints showHints partialCredit showLengthHints )) {
00355         $options{$o} = $opts{$o} || 0;
00356     }
00357     $options{showUnionReduceWarnings} = $opts{showUnionReduceWarnings};
00358     $options{studentsMustReduceUnions} = $opts{studentsMustReduceUnions};
00359     if(defined($opts{ordered}) and $opts{ordered}) {
00360         $options{ordered} = 1;
00361         # Force this option if the the union must be ordered
00362         $options{studentsMustReduceUnions} = 1;
00363     }
00364     if (defined($opts{'sloppy'}) && $opts{'sloppy'} eq 'yes') {
00365          $options{requireParenMatch} = 0;
00366     }
00367     # historically we allow more infinities
00368     $context->strings->add(
00369         'i' => {alias=>'infinity'},
00370         'infty' => {alias=>'infinity'},
00371         'minfinity' => {infinite=>1, negative=>1},
00372         'minfty' => {alias=>'minfinity'},
00373         'minf' => {alias=>'minfinity'},
00374         'mi' => {alias=>'minfinity'},
00375     );
00376     # Add any strings
00377     if ($opts{strings}) {
00378         foreach my $string (@{$opts{strings}}) {
00379             $string = uc($string);
00380             $context->strings->add($string) unless
00381                 defined($context->strings->get($string));
00382             $ans_type = 'String' if $string eq uc($correct_ans);
00383         }
00384     }
00385     # Add any variables
00386     $opts{vars} = $opts{var} if ($opts{var});
00387     if ($opts{vars}) {
00388         $context->variables->are(); # clear old vars
00389         $opts{vars} = [$opts{vars}] unless ref($opts{vars}) eq 'ARRAY';
00390         foreach my $v (@{$opts{vars}}) {
00391             $context->variables->add($v=>'Real')
00392                 unless $context->variables->get($v);
00393         }
00394     }
00395     
00396     my $ans_eval;
00397     Context($context);
00398     if($ans_type eq 'List') {
00399         $ans_eval = List($correct_ans)->cmp(%options);
00400     } elsif($ans_type eq 'Union') {
00401         $ans_eval = Union($correct_ans)->cmp(%options);
00402     } elsif($ans_type eq 'String') {
00403         $ans_eval = List($correct_ans)->cmp(%options);
00404     } else {
00405         warn "Bug -- should not be here in interval_cmp";
00406     }
00407         
00408     Context($oldContext);
00409     return($ans_eval);
00410 }
00411 
00412 =head2 number_list_cmp
00413 
00414 Checks an answer which is a comma-separated list of numbers.  The actual
00415 numbers are fed to num_cmp, so all of the flexibilty of num_cmp carries
00416 over (values can be expressions to be evaluated).  For example,
00417 
00418     number_list_cmp("1, -2")
00419 
00420 will accept "1, -2", "-2, 1", or "-1-1,sqrt(1)".
00421 
00422     number_list_cmp("1^2 + 1, 2^2 + 1, 3^2 + 1", ordered=>'strict')
00423 
00424 will accept "2, 5, 10", but not "5, 2, 10".
00425 
00426 If you want to allow complex number entries, complex=>'ok' will cause it
00427 to use cplx_cmp instead:
00428 
00429     number_list_cmp("2, -2, 2i, -2i", complex=>'ok')
00430 
00431 In cases where you set complex=>'ok', be sure the problem file loads
00432 PGcomplexmacros.pl.
00433 
00434 Optional arguements for num_cmp (resp. cplx_cmp) can be used as well,
00435 such as
00436 
00437     number_list_cmp("cos(3), sqrt(111)", relTol => 3)
00438 
00439 The strings=>['hello'] argument is treated specially.  It can be used to
00440 replace the entire answer.  So
00441 
00442     number_list_cmp("cos(3), sqrt(111)", strings=>['none'])
00443 
00444 will mark "none" wrong, but not generate an error.  On the other hand,
00445 
00446     number_list_cmp("none", strings=>['none'])
00447 
00448 will mark "none" as correct.
00449 
00450 One can also specify optionnal arguments for Parser's List checker: showHints,
00451 partialCredit, and showLengthHints, as in:
00452 
00453     number_list_cmp("cos(3), sqrt(111)", partialCredit=>1)
00454 
00455 =cut
00456 
00457 # ^function number_list_cmp
00458 # ^uses Context
00459 # ^uses mode2context
00460 # ^uses List
00461 sub number_list_cmp {
00462     my $list = shift;
00463 
00464     my %num_params = @_;
00465 
00466     my $mode          = $num_params{mode} || 'std';
00467     my %options       = (debug => $num_params{debug});
00468 
00469     #
00470     #  Get an apppropriate context based on the mode
00471     #
00472     my $oldContext = Context();
00473     my $context = mode2context($mode, %num_params);
00474 
00475     #$context->strings->clear;
00476     if ($num_params{strings}) {
00477         foreach my $string (@{$num_params{strings}}) {
00478             my %tex = ($string =~ m/(-?)inf(inity)?/i)? (TeX => "$1\\infty"): ();
00479             $string = uc($string);
00480             $context->strings->add($string => {%tex}) unless
00481                 defined($context->strings->get($string));
00482         }
00483     }
00484 
00485     $options{ordered} = 1 if defined($num_params{ordered});
00486     # These didn't exist before in number_list_cmp so they behaved like
00487     # in List()->cmp.  Now they can be optionally set
00488     for my $o (qw( showHints partialCredit showLengthHints )) {
00489         $options{$o} = $num_params{$o} || 0;
00490     }
00491 
00492     Context($context);
00493     my $ans_eval = List($list)->cmp(%options);
00494     Context($oldContext);
00495     return($ans_eval);
00496 }
00497 
00498 
00499 =heads equation_cmp
00500 
00501 Compares an equation.  This really piggy-backs off of fun_cmp.  It looks
00502 at LHS-RHS of the equations to see if they agree up to constant multiple.
00503 It also guards against an answer of 0=0 (which technically gives a constant
00504 multiple of any equation).  It is best suited to situations such as checking
00505 the equation of a line which might be vertical and you don't want to give
00506 that away, or checking equations of ellipses where the students answer should
00507 be quadratic.
00508 
00509 Typical invocation would be:
00510 
00511     equation_com("x^2+(y-1)^2 = 11", vars=>['x','y'])
00512 
00513 =cut
00514 
00515 # ^function equation_cmp
00516 # ^uses Equation_eval::equation_cmp
00517 sub equation_cmp {
00518     Equation_eval::equation_cmp(@_);
00519 }
